title: High body mass index and cancer risk—a Mendelian randomisation study
author: Benn
author_address: Department of Clinical Biochemistry, Gentofte Hospital, Copenhagen University Hospital, Kildega ̊rdsvej 28, 2900 Gentofte, Denmark
hypothesis: Effect of body mass index on cancer
rationale: High body mass index (BMI) has been associ- ated with increased risk of some cancer. Whether these reflect causal associations is unknown. We examined this issue.
power_calculation_how: Power to exclude a causal risk of cancer (odds ratio) at a two-sided a of 0.05 and b of 80 % was calculated using an online power calculation tool (https://sb452.shi nyapps.io/power/) for instrumental variable analysis in Mendelian Randomization studies with binary outcomes
limitations_pleiotropy: To minimize influence from pleiotropy, we carefully selected genetic instruments and used genetic variants located in five different genes combined in an allele score for body mass index, making it unlikely that the genetic variants in the allele score have the same pleiotropic effects
limitations_statistical_power: Lack of power for rare cancer

title: Mendelian Randomization Study of Body Mass Index and Colorectal Cancer Risk
author: Thrift
author_address: Dan L. Duncan Cancer Center, Baylor College of Medicine, One Baylor Plaza, Houston, TX 77030-3498
hypothesis: Effect of body mass index on colon, rectal, and colorectal cancer
rationale: As risk estimates from observational studies may be biased and/or confounded, we conducted a Mendelian randomization study to estimate the causal association between BMI and colorectal cancer.
exposure_pleiotropy: Looked at association of GRS with potential confounders
MR_method: two-stage control function instrumental variable approach
limitations_overall: A final limitation in this study is the lack of data on tumor molecular phenotype
limitations_pleiotropy: we feel that it is highly unlikely that a large subset of the 77 SNPs in the score would have pleiotropic associations with BMI and colorectal cancer. If the IV is associated with colorectal cancer risk through the same metabolic pathways (e.g., inflammation, oxidative stress, glucose/insulin dysregulation) that are suspected to connect BMI to carcinogenesis, then this second assumption would still hold, as both the IV and BMI would be considered markers of altered metabolic (or related) risk factors.
limitations_statistical_power: our IV analyses may have been underpowered as the IV explained less than 2% of total phenotypic variation for BMI
